Abandoned

It's not a production requirement. Propose closing it.
I think phosphor-pid-control supports this already. If not, it should be added there.

I think phosphor-pid-control doesn't support this feature.

We discussed with Patrick and Josh in this commit: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/58427

We think that it is better to support this feature by adding Zone layer in fan sensors.
Resolved. If there is any question, please let us know. Thanks!
Reopening.  There is already support for Zones.  At a minimum, this needs a unique name to differentiate it from Zones.  At best, the existing zone concept can be reused.

Hi All,
Rebased master and fixed the conflict.
Please help to review agarin. Thanks!
This looks promising. Also, it could be a step towards the idea mentioned here: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/issues/27
This code is performing a prepend, not an append. Please correct this comment.
Done

I am concerned about this changing the syntax of the control/fanpwm and sensors/fan_pwm pathnames. There are many scripts and other programs in the field that depend on these pathnames. I do not want to break them.

Would it be possible to preserve the old syntax, that did not require the user to know the zone number in order to address a particular PWM by name? Maybe create two pathnames, aliased to each other, to avoid breaking existing users?
The zone layer will be added only if the user adds config in entity-manager. it  should be fine if someone don't want to use this feature.

What is meant by "only if the user adds config in entity-manager"? It seems that this code, as it stands now, would require all existing zones in entity-manager Inventory objects to follow this new object path naming scheme. That would break a lot of existing configurations in the field.

I like the idea of the new feature, but breaking existing configurations is unacceptable. People have scripts and other tools that depend on the existing device path layout. Perhaps have a flag that can be given at compile time, to opt into this new behavior, such as https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/+/58009

That way, the existing object path layout, which are depended upon by many people, will not need to suddenly change.

It is not required of configuring existing zones in entity-manager inventory. We tested function with and without zones configured in entity-manager.

With zones configured, the object path will be like:
```
         `-/xyz
          `-/xyz/openbmc_project
            |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control
            | `-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm
            |   `-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Zone_0
            |     |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Zone_0/Pwm_1
            |     |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Zone_0/Pwm_2
            |     |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Zone_0/Pwm_3
            |     `-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Zone_0/Pwm_4
            `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors
              |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm
              | `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Zone_0
              |   |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Zone_0/Pwm_1
              |   |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Zone_0/Pwm_2
              |   |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Zone_0/Pwm_3
              |   `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Zone_0/Pwm_4
              `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach
                |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/BB_FAN0_TACH_RPM
                |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/BB_FAN1_TACH_RPM
                |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/BB_FAN2_TACH_RPM
                `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/BB_FAN3_TACH_RPM
```

Without zones configured:
```
        `-/xyz
          `-/xyz/openbmc_project
            |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control
            | `-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm
            |   `-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm
            |     |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Pwm_1
            |     |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Pwm_2
            |     |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Pwm_3
            |     `-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Pwm_4
            `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors
              |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm
              | `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm
              |   |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Pwm_1
              |   |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Pwm_2
              |   |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Pwm_3
              |   `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Pwm_4
              `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach
                |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/BB_FAN0_TACH_RPM
                |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/BB_FAN1_TACH_RPM
                |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/BB_FAN2_TACH_RPM
                `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/BB_FAN3_TACH_RPM
```
Marked resolved. Feel free to leave more feedback if you have any.
I recommend changing sysPath to be vector<string> sysPaths. Then, you can have a vector of strings, instead of having to use a space-separated string.
Change to vector. It did affect codes at different place and we also modified them.
I am curious why Zone types do not want their association created.
Added Zone type to assiciation creation.

I recommend using a member variable that is vector<string> instead of "space separated strings".
This will save the overhead of having to recover the vector from the space-separated string every time.
Done
Thanks. I am still concerned about the fact this changes the location of objects already well-established in the field.
I am still concerned by this. Was this addressed?

Can you be more specific on the concern with object_paths changing?  Shouldn't everyone be using mapper?  Or are there some config files in openbmc/openbmc pointing to "old" paths that may also need to be updated?

There's a lot of people, especially testers performing thermal tuning with ovens and chambers, who might be unfamiliar with Object Mapper and are relying on example `busctl` command lines given to them by the software developers. There's probably a lot of scripts also in the field. I am concerned about changing everybody's paths suddenly.

While I understand and sympathize with the concern, we can't prevent making open source changes due to scripts people have downstream, right?  The object paths have never been intended to be an external API.

Is there any possibility for the open source project to satisfy your concerns?

Makes sense. I just think they need to be changed for a good reason. Is this a good reason, merely to add a convenience feature to change all the fan settings at once, instead of changing each fan setting individually?
Trying to figure that part out. ;)
Change to std::vector<std::string> pwmPaths({ pwmPathStr }); and moved to line 280.
Or just change it to `{ pwmPaths }` here.
Done
Gentle reminder: please help to review again. Thanks.

This zone pwmSensor also has the sensor.value  interface. Have you checked on redfish sensors URI and ipmitool sdr?. I think it would show up an another sensor in both places. Is that what we want? I think that is a little confusing.

We found that the redfish sensors URI didn't show up another sensor for it. The ipmi sdr shew up another sensor for it. We think it should be fine because the zone sensor is the largest value of the pwm sensor's in zone.

However, we did find a bug when getting sensor reading via redfish URI. We revise the code and the dbus path will be like:
```
busctl tree xyz.openbmc_project.FanSensor
`-/xyz
  `-/xyz/openbmc_project
    |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control
    | `-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm
    |   |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Pwm_1
    |   |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Pwm_2
    |   |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Pwm_3
    |   |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Pwm_4
    |   |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Zone_0
    |   | |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Zone_0/Pwm_1
    |   | `-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Zone_0/Pwm_2
    |   `-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Zone_1
    |     |-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Zone_1/Pwm_3
    |     `-/xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm/Zone_1/Pwm_4
    |-/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory
    `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors
      |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm
      | |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Pwm_1
      | |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Pwm_2
      | |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Pwm_3
      | |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Pwm_4
      | |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Zone_0
      | | |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Zone_0/Pwm_1
      | | `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Zone_0/Pwm_2
      | `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Zone_1
      |   |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Zone_1/Pwm_3
      |   `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Zone_1/Pwm_4
      `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach
        |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/BB_FAN0_TACH_RPM
        |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/BB_FAN1_TACH_RPM
        |-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/BB_FAN2_TACH_RPM
        `-/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/BB_FAN3_TACH_RPM
```

Do you have any concern about this implementation?
I will give this a try and report back
Shall we upload the new patch for this change first?
Update the patches to revise the code.

> We found that the redfish sensors URI didn't show up another sensor for it. 

This is only because there was no association added to a chassis.  The sensors are likely still returning in the subtree result, but bmcweb doesn't know what to do with them, and excludes them when doing the chassis scan.  This design needs rethought, because there's nothing stopping this new PWM from getting added to the non-chassis driven APIs (IPMI).

function return type is uint32_t
ic - it is an existing bug.  Would be nice to fix it, no changes are made to this function
Done
same here
Done
should error condition return na?
Done

A one sentence description is rarely enough for a completely new feature.

From which user-facing interface is this feature used?
How is a user expected to use it?
What other features exist that already use the term "Zone" and how do they relate?

This doesn't look right.  A PID loop would be attached to a Zone, not a fan.  A pwm might exist in multiple zones at once.  Attaching a zone value to a fan would imply that we're changing things at the wrong level, or we need to invent new vernacular other than "zone".


What I suspect is that your system takes a 1:1 zone -> fan mapping.  Unfortunately, that's not all system designs, so we'll need to come up with a new object here.

This path doesn't exist in PDI, and is unlikely how we would model this type of API, as these paths would now show up in subtree results when scanning for sensors.

In Dbus we would generally come up with another type, outside of the sensors namespace to hold the idea of a "Zone".

We have changed the design for adding the fan zone layer.
Would like to ask is there any concern about this commit?

This looks clean, but I don't see the need for this, other than a convenience feature of being able to get/set all fans in the zone by using a single object that represents the entire zone. Is there a use case for having a unified sensor like this, versus simply setting each individual fan in the zone individually?
+1 here. Why is this change needed?

As Josh said, this is a convenience feature of being able to get/set all fans in the zone by using a single object that represents the entire zone.

If you think that there is no need for this, we can discuss with Patrick if we still need this feature.

Does this change only act as a convenience for "manual mode" setting of all the fans in a zone, or is it also intended to be used by phosphor-pid-control to ensure there is a single value applied across all the fans in a zone?

If this is only for "manual mode", I don't think it is all that beneficial.
If this is useful to simplify the calculation complexity by the fan control algorithm in phosphor-pid-control it seems useful.

Overall, this feature needs to:

Document why it's needed from a user perspective.  What user-facing APIs are we adding?  How are they used?  If this is only for dbus-based debug, we need to state that explicitly.

Resolve the Dbus interfacing issues.  This patch is creating objects at paths that aren't correct (zone-named sub folders within the sensors subsystem) and likely need a new Dbus interface to store the idea of a collection of fans/pwms, or a set of fans.

Document why the existing control interfaces don't work for this use case.  PID/Stepwise control loops already have a Zone concept (example below [1]).  I suspect that:

A. This code should've extended the existing Zone concept, and the author just wasn't aware it already existed.  Keep in mind, setting OutLimitMin and OutLimitMax to the same value will effectively give you the same result (I think?).  It would be pretty trivial to wrap that into its own property.
Or
B. This code should've picked a term other than Zone (possibly FanGroup?) to describe something different.

When you extend the user-facing behavior statement in the commit message, it will make it much more clear if you intend A or B, and we can work on interfacing from there.

Resolve the coding issues.  As is this is:
- Reading from sysfs for every property read and for in-process communication, which is an anti-pattern and leads to deadlocks on hardware/driver problems.  If the PWMs within a process need to cooperate, we shouldn't be using sysfs to do it.
- Duplicating PWM sensors without any interface-facing way to determine that this is a group of PWMs, and not an individual PWM.  This is a problem for user-facing interfaces like Redfish that need to differentiate between outputs that physically exist, and ones that only logically exist.
- Extending the /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors namespace to include the new "zone" concept, without any documentation or justification as to why we didn't follow the more common dbus conventions (coming up with a new grouping object separate from sensors).  If this is really the best path, that needs documented.
- Extending already way too long lambda functions to make them even longer, without any sort of refactoring.

The above will all need to be resolved before this can merge.


Was there any prior discussions about this feature?  If so, can you link them?

[1] https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/9bac6409d4bd684f058517f41de33ba1d17e5666/configurations/a2ul16riser.json#L43
I will defer to Ed's concerns on this.

This lambda is already insanely long, and needs refactored.  Just adding more code to it makes the already bad problem worse.

Please refactor in a commit ahead of adding this new feature, or refactor your code in such a way that this lambda doesn't get longer.
Why are we clearing pwmPaths here?  I suspect we just need to declare PWMPaths in the appropriate scope so that it only applies to where we intend it to.  There's lots of branches outside of this.
why generic string?
This is redundant.  If zoneSet is empty the loop on 585 won't execute.

This doesn't look like the right abstraction.  We shouldn't be creating yet another PWM sensor, which includes a lot of things that I suspect we don't want in a group of sensors (min/max calculations, etc)


I suspect we want a new object that ONLY implements the         /xyz/openbmc_project/control/fanpwm objects?
Unrelated #include change?
Why is this static?
If the iostream isn't good, we no longer return an error?  0 might be valid for some of these interfaces?
Same here?
This is now going to sysfs for every value chance, which is a generalized anti pattern, and causes the dbus APIs to be very slow.
s/chance/change/g

uint32_t doesn't have a NAN value.  I'm a little surprised this compiles.  Notice the documentation:

https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/types/numeric_limits/quiet_NaN


"Only meaningful if std::numeric_limits<T>::has_quiet_NaN == true."

I suspect std::numeric_limits<uint32_t>::has_quiet_NaN returns false, and therefore this value shouldn't be used.  Maybe you meant min here?
Missing error handling.  You've changed the results to return 0, but don't handle if it's 0.
the Sensor subclass already has a sensorType property, so this is effectively shadowing it.  WHy?
